answers.answer: A highly observant patient and a skilled refractionist can probably define a RX considently to within +/- .25 diopters. However many patients cannot tell changes as large as .0.75 diopters.  Diabetes can also cause fluctuating glasses RXA phoropter is more accurate and much faster for most people.JCH III MD

A prescription within a +/-.25 diopter margin of error should therefore pose no problem since corrections are at least a whole digit and will improve the patient's vision by that much anyway.But what about the corrections for astigmatism? Are the measurements also dependent on the patient's subjective response during the test or are they independent of it and thus more accurate? What is the usual margin of error for the cylindrical and axis values? Can errors in these values affect vision adversely?
Same stats and within 5 degrees in the axis.In a visual adult wearing the "wrong" prescription will not damage the eye in any way but may cause discomfort, blurred vision and eye strain.JCH III MD
